title: GeRT - Generalising Robot Manipulation Tasks

author: Christoph Borst, Institute of Robotics and Mechatronics, German Aerospace Center (DLR)

segmentation: So I will try to give you an overview of the project called Kurt with T at the end.
It's about generalizing robot manipulation tasks, not in general, but in a very special manner.
And I am the coordinator of the project and there's a project website where you can find details.
So in 20 minutes is not.

Either we change one of these things, then we have to reprogram and robust programs need at first expertise and time and we are dealer know that 'cause every every year we have to produce a new nice demo for our Institute director and it takes us a lot of time.
So the question is, can we reuse these programs so to somehow form a database and then combine them to new nice demonstration things?
OK, the state of the art in manipulation we, we said is we can use a small set of previously known object.
So there's object recognition and localization done very well.
The geometry of the objects are normally known in advance, so and there might be minor changes in scene arrangements so that we can use motion planners.
The goal configurations should be reachable somehow and most approaches for speed reasons use offline grass planning, so we have.
Some databases with some pre stored grass when we select the best suitable one and simple objects and simple tasks.
So robustness of operation is far from suitable for daily use.
We have simple objects and in many talks we see only pick and place operations.
Ingat we try to do the following, so that's about the generalization station we we try to look on tasks that have the same cost constraints.
For example, pouring in some liquid's from a bottle into a glass and what might change are the objects geometry.
So we will use different glasses or different cups or different bottles, but the task should stay the same and we might have also different object position stats.

What we try to get from Azira later explained from example programs, and that's the thing that is, from our view of roboticists, difficult to get 'cause the task constraints somehow are related to the objects.
And if you only see the geometry or the color or something, the appearance of the object, it's difficult to to.

So the key aspects that we have to face with is planning, so we need to have some task plans or programs that that can adapt for those new task variations and we need perception to determine the similarities between those objects.
